summary: Email chain between Florence Hutner, General Counsel for the NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME), and an unnamed federal prosecutor (likely from USAO-SDNY) regarding redactions to the Jeffrey Epstein autopsy report and related files. The prosecutor requests withholding of scene photos, 360 scans, and information from federal authorities, citing an ongoing criminal investigation.

persons.name: Florence Hutner
persons.role: General Counsel, Office of Chief Medical Examiner
persons.context: Correspondent representing the NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) in discussions with federal prosecutors about redacting the Epstein autopsy file.

persons.name: Rebekah
persons.context: Federal prosecutor communicating with OCME's General Counsel about redaction requests for the Epstein autopsy file, including scene photos and 360 scans.

connections.description: Communicating about legal and procedural matters regarding redactions to the Jeffrey Epstein autopsy file.

events.title: Initial Redaction Request
events.description: Federal prosecutor (Rebekah) sends initial secure message to OCME's General Counsel regarding redactions to the Epstein file.

events.title: Redaction Clarifications
events.description: Email exchange where OCME seeks clarification on the scope and duration of redaction requests for scene photos and 360 scans related to Epstein's death.

events.title: Revised Report Provided
events.description: Federal prosecutor provides a revised version of the OCME report with one redaction removed and requests a specific disclosure notice about redactions related to the ongoing federal investigation.

locations: 421 E. 26th Street, New York, NY 10016 (Office of Chief Medical Examiner)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) requested redactions of material obtained from federal authorities in the Jeffrey Epstein autopsy file, citing an ongoing criminal investigation.
Requested redactions included scene photographs and a 360-degree scan taken by the OCME, indicating these materials contained information relevant to the federal investigation.
The federal prosecutor clarified the redactions were not intended to be permanent but for the duration of the investigation, and OCME would be notified if they no longer needed to be withheld.
OCME noted it would comply with court orders for the unredacted file but would notify federal authorities to allow them to seek to preserve investigative confidentiality.
